results.title: Bayside reflections: Port Phillip Bay on film
results.brief_description: A two-part series composed of archival films, newsreels, stills and personal stories about Port Phillip Bay and its surrounds, its history, architect, beaches, piers and lifestyle from the late 1800s through to the 1990s.
results.title_for_label: Bayside reflections: Port Phillip Bay on film

results.title: The Top end
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Bayside reflections: Port Phillip Bay on film”.
Final part of a most comprehensive and fascinating two part history of Port Phillip Bay, dating back from the 1880s to present times and incorporating archival footage, both professional and amateur, to cover over a century of settlement in Port Phillip Bay. Part two focuses on the northern end of Port Phillip Bay, particularly the areas of Port Melbourne and St Kilda reflecting on their maritime histories and the inevitable changes each city has undergone over the last hundred years or so. From the days of royal visits arriving at St Kilda Pier to the huge passenger liners and warships docking at Port Melbourne’s Station Pier, through to remembering St Kilda when it was “the place in which to be seen” - Melbourne’s favourite playground for fun and leisure, swimming and sailing - to today’s commercial developments and resident protests to maintain the architectural heritage of both Port Melbourne and St Kilda. Broken up into six segments, this documentary also covers some of the Bay’s well-known sea baths, piers and beaches, famous (and some infamous) celebrities, politicians and sporting personalities, historical landmarks, buildings and events and provides some rare and nostalgic images of bygone times. Commentary by Paul Higgins.

group.title: Bayside reflections: Port Phillip Bay on film

group_siblings.title: The Southern portion

results.title: The Southern portion
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Bayside reflections: Port Phillip Bay on film”.
Part one of a most comprehensive and fascinating two part history of Port Phillip Bay, dating back from the 1880’s to present times and incorporating archival footage, both professional and amateur, to cover over a century of settlement in Port Phillip Bay. In particular, focus is on the two main southern peninsulas of Mornington and Bellarine, including Queenscliff, Point Lonsdale, Geelong, Portsea, Sorrento, Mornington and Frankston. The program is divided into seven segments and covers many topics including paddle steamers, fishing, boating, maritime disasters and dramatic rescues, lighthouses, filmmaking, storytelling, environmental issues and the people and architecture of the time. Composed entirely of original film and uses newsreels, documentaries, tourism promotions, advertisements, home movies, dramatic features and short subjects. Commentary by Paul Higgins.

results.title: The Avengers
results.brief_description: Espionage, fantasy and a healthy dose of unresolved sexual tension abound in this slick series that has proved to be one of the most successful television series of all time. Originally aired in the UK between January 1961 and September 1969 and comprising of 161 episodes, the series went on to screen in a record number of 120 countries. John Steed (Patrick McNee) was always an Avenger, appearing in all episodes - Mrs Peel (Diana Rigg) was his third and most enduring partner. The series was resurrected in the mid 1970s, episodes of which are also available in the collection.

results.title: Death at bargain prices. Castle De'ath. The Master minds
results.creator_credit: Julian Wintle and Associated British Picture Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Avengers”.
Death at bargain prices: When a murdered agent is found carrying a receipt from the children’s section of Pinter’s department store Mrs Peel finds herself working in lingerie. Steed discovers the mysterious disappearance of food from the store as well as regular customer Professor Popple. “Castle De’ath”: Mrs Peel goes undercover as a publicity consultant with ABORCASHAAT (Advisory Bureau on Refurbishing Castles and Stately Homes as a Tourist Attraction) at De’ath Castle; Steed is a kilt wearing historian investigating the 13th Laird of De’ath, Black Jimmy. There’s ghosts of traitors past, mysterious pipers, a dungeon and plenty of tartan from the Avengers. Gordon Jackson stars. “The Master minds”: When Sir Clive Todd is found to be involved with a string of burglaries the government is keen to solve matters quietly and quickly. Mrs Peel plays Florence Nightingale to the amnesiac Sir Clive who was shot in the latest robbery and Steed attempts to find the mastermind behind the successful outfit.

group_siblings.title: The Hour that never was. Murdersville
The House that Jack built. Never, never say die
The Town of no return. The Gravediggers. The Cybernauts
Two's a crowd. Mission highly impropable

results.title: The Town of no return. The Gravediggers. The Cybernauts
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Avengers”.
The Town of no return: Steed and Mrs Peel are sent to the sleepy seaside town of Little Bazeley to investigate the disappearance of four agents. In a town where nobody is what they seem, Peel and Steed disguise themselves as a primary school teacher and property developer and stay at a local hotel called the Gremlin. The highlight of the episode is a leather clad Peel tied down with horse riding apparel. “The Gravediggers”: there’s interference in sector three on the radar, leading to a fear of undetected nuclear weapons. Steed and Mrs Peel head to the town of Prinby, located in the heart of sector three and the burial place of Dr Hubert Marlowe, recently deceased expert in the field. Peel goes undercover as a Nurse at a hospice for railwaymen while Steed visits the benefactor of the establishment. Highlights of the episode include a miniature train ride and Mrs Peel tied to the railway tracks, complete with accompanying music, fitting for a damsel in distress. “The Cybernauts”: three electronics experts are killed by a tall man with brute strength and the number is increasing. They all had an appointment with the Harachi Corporation, an electronics company who have created a new circuit element for transistors. The trail leads Steed and Mrs Peel to United Automation where a wheelchair bound scientist is building an army of radio controlled cybernauts. A highlight of the episode involves Mrs Peel doing karate - in a skirt.

results.title: The Many faces of epilepsy
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Speaking from experience”.
Epilepsy affects 3% of the Australian population and manifests itself in many different ways to individuals, families and communities. Epilepsy sufferers and their families discuss the symptoms they experience (varying from stumbling, absent seizures, tonic clonic), the success/failure and side effects of medication, reaction to diagnosis, what it feels like to have a seizure (daydreaming, contortion, deja vu), how the symptoms change with age, warning signs, the impact on employment and relationships, disclosure and impact on lifestyle.

results.title: Epilepsy in childhood
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Speaking from experience”.
Parents and children discuss the circumstances and behaviour that led to their child being diagnosed with epilepsy, ranging from seizures to staring into space. They explain their very personal initial reaction to the news, deciding whether to medicate or not, the importance of a good relationship with medical staff, the impact on family and friends, schooling, lifestyle changes, and how their children have changed with age and on receiving medication.

results.title: Living with breast cancer
results.creator_credit: Gillian Fawcett, Giovanna Pignaiosa, Anti Cancer Council, Cancer Council Victoria and Speaking From Experience
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Speaking from experience”.
Breast cancer is a malignant tumor in the breast. The severity of the disease depends on the size of the cancer and whether it has spread to other parts of the body. This excellent and informative documentary presents five women of varying age, who have all experienced the trauma of breast cancer. Each woman relates her own personal story from the initial diagnosis and having to deal with the reality, to surgery and treatment and finally to recovery and the future. Various types of surgery, chemotherapy, and radiotherapy are discussed including the side effects, physical and emotional, and the important role self-image can play in the road to recovery. Also stresses that the key to recovery is through support from family and friends in terms of encouragement, offers of help in daily routines, and generally in just being there. A common factor with each of the women is the way their outlook on life has changed, valuing each day as precious and maintaining a positive attitude as a means to coping with the disease. A warm and enlightening progam.
